txt: Current policy initiatives such as tighter rules for property investors and measures to increase the supply of land for development are are sufficient to address housing affordability.
Measures to address the cost of building materials will help with housing affordability.
Increasing building employees skills and productivity in the the construction sector will improve housing affordability.
Increasing the level of innovation in the building sector will improve housing affordability.
Helping developers with the provision of infrastructure and streamlining the regulatory regime will improve housing affordability.
New Zealand’s housing market needs urgent reform to ensure that the rate of building keeps up with household formation and demographics.
Property speculation is artificially driving up the price of houses since housing offers investors some of the best passive returns on offer.
Limiting immigration and foreign ownership won’t make housing affordable as there are more than enough domestic buyers eager to make a profit or just get on the property ladder to keep prices up.
Simply opening up more land and cutting regulations won’t make housing affordable.
If it’s just left to the market, builders and developers won’t build smaller cheaper houses.
Improving the productivity in the construction sector helps the sector with its margins but it doesn’t necessarily affect affordability.
Tax incentives are needed to encourage more affordable houses to be built.
The tax system needs to be changed so that returns on property investments don't disadvantage (prospective)homeowners compared with those who own and rent multiple properties.
The state should build and own a sizable stock of affordable houses outside the free-market.
The key to solving the housing affordability crisis will be to incentivise councils to embrace growth.
Infrastructure could be funded by allowing owners and developers to access private capital by issuing bonds and charging residents a property tax.
Councils could be eligible for Housing Encouragement Grants based on the delivery of agreed numbers of new houses.
To solve the problem requires real leadership with a long-term focus and commitment that is at odds with NZ’s central and local government electoral cycles.
Setting up new independent organisations in areas of high housing demand with representatives from across the housing system will provide the leadership necessary to provide affordable housing.

Developing a non-partisan “homes accord” that all political parties can sign-up to and which aims to address the affordability issue with long-term solutions is a vital piece of the affordability jigsaw.
When land costs rise to specified level, councils must release new land for purchase and development.
Council constraints on development such as height limits, minimum dwelling size or urban-rural boundaries must be cut to a minimum to support the right level of building for housing needs.
Any council or crown land that is not reserve land or corridors for services must be released for purchase by developers.
Constraints on landlords must remain low so tenants can find suitable accommodation from the options on offer.
Infrastructure bonds could make an attractive option to fund the provision of housing services such as drainage, water supply and power.
I live in a city
I live in a town
I live in a rural area
I own 1 housing unit
I own more than 1 housing units
I live in my family-owned property without paying rent
I live in rented accommodation
I live in emergency housing or social housing
I am under 30 years of age
I am 30 years of age or older but less than 55
I  am 55 years of age or older
My household income is less than $100,000
My household income is $100,000 or greater but less than $150,000
My household income is $150,000 or greater
I have dependents
I work in the field of housing
To be affordable housing must be long-term sustainable.  It must be pleasant to live in - obey minimum room sizes; heights; daylighting etc.
Growth in housing loan credit from $50b to $240bn has fuelled this fire
Net migration has increased competition for the available homes
Rental property investor tax breaks have increased competition for the available homes
Allowing 7bn overseas people to purchase homes here has increased competition for the available homes
Social and Community Housing and the non-market rents they offer is an important part of the overall affordable housing mix.
when the Nats first came to power, I seem to recall they were going to investigate the cost of building materials.
Construction methods need streamlining - currently too costly and labour intensive.
speculators need to be kept out of the market. Speculation is parasitic.
Interest-free loans, flexible repayments.   Better than paying rent & a good investment.
Renting could be a viable sustainable option.  Long-term renting eg 5 years, 10 years, 20 years should be the norm..
There is also a role for local Maori and community responses to provide quality affordable housing.
Any supply of land for development should have at least 20% affordable housing.
Anecdotal evidence suggests to me that foreign speculators/ investors are a major force in driving house prices up.
Please proof read your questions carefully as there are errors which make the meaning obscure (spelling mistakes, lack of apostrophe etc).
How have you come up with your questions? So far there are distinct biases emerging such as bias in favour of home ownership.
Remember over 50% of kiwis rent. Renting should be an acceptable option & tenants should have same security as home owners.
Rental properties need a health and accessability WOF
Prevent foreign investors from purchasing existing property, but allow them to build new houses.
Housing providers should be incentivised to the point that creating affordable housing becomes the most lucrative market to develop in.
Agencies of the Crown and Local Government (CCOs) need to have a clear mandate to deliver community centered outcomes.
These questions are too badly worded to be meaningful.
Significantly increasing taxes on owners of multiple properties will improve housing affordability.
It is important that focusing on lowering costs (e.g. materials) doesn't make us lose sight of housing quality.
Special Housing Areas are a sham that enables big developers to sidestep the RMA while only providing a token percentage of affordable units
agree
The issue is one of government capability. Does the private sector or the elected government make the final decision?
Who makes the decision? Currently it's the private sector,  abetted by Government complicity. Some call this fascism.
Reduce Immigration. Immigration levels are closely tied to property valuation change. Imm and property valuation change are closely linked.
REDUCE IMMIGRATION. This will immediately increase housing affordability.  We have the highest levels of Immigration per capi in the world.
owner-occupiers should get the same tax breaks as investors on interest and maintenance
We will only solve the housing crisis if all parties - public, private and not for profit sector work together
Current policy initiatives, such as tighter rules for property investors and measures to increase the supply of land for development, are sufficient to address housing affordability.
Increasing building employees skills and productivity in the construction sector will improve housing affordability.
The tax system needs to be changed so that returns on property investments don't disadvantage (prospective) homeowners compared with those who own and rent multiple properties.
Govt. mortgages at lower than bank interest rates be made available by HousingCorp. Making repayments affordable for low income people.
Foreigners whose home country does not allow 'Free Hold Ownership' by NZers to have no rights to purchase in NZ.
One fast improvement is to allow individuals to convert existing large houses into multiple dwellings by reducing council constraints.
Properly enforce a 'Property Traders' tax. Resale of a residential property in less than 5 years then income tax levied on profit.
Squatters Rights: Residences left vacant for more than 4 months can be legally squatted by the homeless.
Jib board costs are many, many times higher in NZ than Australia, US and EU. Monopoly practices seem to be behind this.
Make apartments more affordable by reducing less critical requirements, eg for carparks if public transport exists
Wellington is bound by insane height restrictions based on flat standards for other regions.
Recognise, easily attainable home ownership increases a person’s stake in society and makes a fairer society. Goal of 90% home ownership.
WCC's resource consent dept is a profit centre.
Make apartments more affordable by allowing more floors where the height doesn't impact safety or neighborhood well-being
make rural 10 acre minimum section subdivisions more flexible. Minimal, unprofitable farming land, could allow for many new homes.
Significant wage rises to make the housing component of living costs affordable.
A five year rent freeze to let wages catch up and to decrease the desirability of property for speculation.
None of the questions are around better paying jobs, bring back manufacturing and the better paying jobs that come with it.
Greater provision is required for emergency housing, social housing (not jsut government provided) and assisted home ownership.
$500,000 is not an affordable house.
Banks should be required to hold more capital against loans to property investors - increasing their cost of borrowing
Housing is currently the safest place for your money. LVT's and capital gains taxes will help drive investment out of housing and into R&D.
My household income is less than $50,000
Setting Loan to Value Ratios and a capital gains taxes would help to drive investment out of housing and into productive spending like research and development.
Greater provision is required for emergency housing, social housing (not just government provided) and assisted home ownership.
The need for more land to be made available
More land needs to be made available.
There needs to be a different form of leadership i.e a collective one of all the players - rather than relying on Government or Council
The bit above on  opinion groups is completely confusing. It means nothing to me.Completely confusing. !!!!!!!!!
Yes
The State should build good examples of affordable, desirable medium &high density housing, to show private builders/buyers what is possible
There is a requirement to develop a rental market that delivers secure, affordable and healthy housing for low to moderate income earners.
Place housing and housing affordability as a key consideration in macro policy making and planning.
Deliver flexible tailored policy responses that facilitate different policy responses in different regions and housing markets.
Policy responses required to address the interactions between housing and broader economic, social and environmental goals of government.
Policy responses must be based on strong evidence for setting local and affordable housing supply targets.
The negative social and economic impacts of un-affordable housing needs to be on the table.
New Zealand has one of the least rental-friendly policy settings in the world.  This must change to deliver affordable rental properties.
Policy makers should consider all location-related costs when attempting to address housing affordability.
The Auckland Unitary Plan, with its more liberal development ethos, has had zero impact on housing affordability.
The housing crisis is a result of the asset inflation caused by a glut of money being borrowed into the economy by banks.
Housing Bubbles can be avoided by taking the power to create money away from banks, as advocated by organisations like positivemoney.org
NZ should reintroduce a land tax
To fix affordable housing a policy framework that recognises the role councils play in social housing and treats councils on the same basis as community housing providers is needed.
There should be a rent ceiling aligned to average wage per household so landlords can't keep on raising the rent.
Re-introduce state houses, built by the state and rented out by the state so that everyone has a house.
Firstly, recognise that universal access to healthy, affordable housing (owned or rented) should be a goal of any political party or NZ govt
Foreign ownership of residential properties when we are in a housing crisis is short-term thinking resulting in long-term pain for NZers.
NZers living in stable, affordable homes are given a secure base to contribute and participate in their community, and their society.
Elevated land taxes should be charged on undeveloped residentially zoned land to offset the economic benefits of landbanking.
The market will never deliver the housing supply required to address the crisis.
NZ Govt will have financial benefits in terms of health, community, education and crime as a return on investment in state housing.
State housing once offered should be secured tenancy for those tenants.  They should have the freedom to houseshare, offer accommodation etc
State housing sold, should retain at a minimum the same number of state housing units in that particular location to avoid gentrification.
Higher rates and land taxes should be charged on holiday homes which contribute to whole communities being emptied of residents.
Govt department should be set up to help co-housing and cooperative methods of development for small groups that intend to reside there.
Government should stop all foreign investment and advise that properties will be purchased by them at the (lower) purchase or market price.
Affordable homes index used by overseas, is not a good measure in NZ when utilities and food costs are often higher.
Affordable housing index (overseas) does not take into account the planning in NZ that often results in higher transport and commuter costs.
Until real wages and income rise, housing (whether rented or bought) will remain affordable for many.
Innovative methods for housing need to be encouraged and monitored by local and national government.  Such as laneway houses, etc
Current Government initiatives are inadequate to meet the housing needs of New Zealand's poorest families.
Government needs to consider the impact of construction rules on new and existing house prices.  eg wind, quake, glass and scaffold rules
Innovative methods for housing need to be encouraged and monitored by local and national government. Such as laneway houses, tiny houses and co-housing arrangements.
Until real wages and income rise, housing (whether rented or bought) will remain unaffordable for many.
State housing needs to be considered as a government providing for the needs of a good society, not as a temporary stopgap.
Perspective 2
Bring back State Advances and fair interest loans.
Build 100 sq metre homes, one bathroom, no garage, no fences, no  driveway. People will build these once they are housed & can afford it.
Take out developers, instead allow Councils to develop and sell sections.
Interventions supporting people into homes worked in 1975. "Old thinking" is not wrong or anti-business. It IS NZ the way I want it!
All land should be subject to an annual land tax based on the land value and billed with rates. Reduce income tax rates a little to offset.
Leadership of fixing the housing crisis in Auckland to come from city leaders - rather than expecting the Government or Council to lead
The cost of building materials needs to come down.
Body corporate rules make apartment ownership unattractive
Supply of public land for development should have 20% for affordable housing but   the 20% requirement should be monitored effectively
Reducing  regulations and allowing self regulation in the building industry  risks enabling  a Grenfell Tower like disaster to occur in NZ
An average household income should be enough to buy an average-priced house.
If an 'affordable' houses cost no more than 3 times the median/average household income, more than half the new houses need to be affordable
Government leaders using semantic gymnastics to deny  the housing crisis distract from the serious long term  social ills it is causing
The massive global housing boom has been related to the Interest rates being at all time lows for too long.  Extreme low rates = booms.
That is the symptom.  Property speculation increases or decreases with the level of Interest Rates and the all time lows foster this.
This is a really dumb type of forum, the comments are too short to say anything useful. Soundbite thinking for the mental gerbil generation.
When land for housing is so scarce, it is wrong for the Crown to own as much land as it does that is not used for housing.
There should be a cap on how many residential properties any private entity may own.
Shift tax emphasis from income to assets
Capital gains tax should be payable on all property sales.  There is no good reason to exempt the family home and good reason not to.
We need more intensive, energy efficient and livable dwellings built to meet demand for housing in cities and reduce sprawl and traffic
Cheap money through low interest rates from overseas money (from banks) have created most of the problem.
a person should not be allowed to own more than one house.
In Taupo Penny Homes can make homes which sell for under $400,000.  Get developers like this company to build elsewhere
Shelter and accomodation are basic human requirements, having this available to evenryone in NZ should be a priority.
